item.title: Infinite Monkey Theorem
item.dc:creator: @_bool
item.description:
@_bool wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:24, topic:347553”][quote author=Adam link=topic=443931.msg3261459#msg3261459 date=1278532633]

But the monkeys wouldn’t ever finish because there is an infinite amount of moneys, a never ending supply of typing couldn’t ever end.

One will finish, that is the point. But why just get them to write Shakespeare? Let them do something useful, like programing something or write down the instruction for a quantum-computer.

^ because if you know what you’re looking for, it’d be easier just to write it yourself than wait an unknown amount of time for some random program to write it for you. There doesn’t seem to be any typical use in a program like this…
[/quote]
I mean it seriously, learn the program some rules to make it output proper code, then find a way to measure the best code and use a evolutionary way of mutations, but now we are way out of the topic.

But the monkeys wouldn’t ever finish because there is an infinite amount of moneys, a never ending supply of typing couldn’t ever end.

One will finish, that is the point. But why just get them to write Shakespeare? Let them do something useful, like programing something or write down the instruction for a quantum-computer.

What if one never finishes what if it goes on for infinity and keeps going, never striking the right sequence of keys?

Yes, one WILL one only press “S” for infinity of time (But the probability is infinite low), but this does not matter, since the theorem does not say that everyone will finish.[/quote]
I’m saying none of them might finish.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:

One will finish, that is the point. But why just get them to write Shakespeare? Let them do something useful, like programing something or write down the instruction for a quantum-computer.
[/quote]
^ because if you know what you’re looking for, it’d be easier just to write it yourself than wait an unknown amount of time for some random program to write it for you. There doesn’t seem to be any typical use in a program like this…[/quote]
I mean it seriously, learn the program some rules to make it output proper code, then find a way to measure the best code and use a evolutionary way of mutations, but now we are way out of the topic.

[quote="(Anthony), post:23, topic:347553"][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=443931.msg3261444#msg3261444 date=1278531667]

But the monkeys wouldn’t ever finish because there is an infinite amount of moneys, a never ending supply of typing couldn’t ever end.

One will finish, that is the point. But why just get them to write Shakespeare? Let them do something useful, like programing something or write down the instruction for a quantum-computer.
[/quote]
What if one never finishes what if it goes on for infinity and keeps going, never striking the right sequence of keys?[/quote]
Yes, one WILL one only press “S” for infinity of time (But the probability is infinite low), but this does not matter, since the theorem does not say that everyone will finish.

item.title: Infinite Monkey Theorem
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:16, topic:347553”][quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=443931.msg3261166#msg3261166 date=1278505414]
Ohh i was thinking there was an infinite amount of monkeys, not time, because of mopmans example in another topic:

exactly, enough monkeys will win a war through statistics

how can the infinite monkey theorem be simulated =/

Could you prove the theorem with a quantum computer?

I dunno why you’re asking me that lol. My opinion would be no, because you can’t simulate an infinite amount of time, even with a quantum computer. You may be able to simulate an infinite amount of monkeys though…
[/quote]
If you had infinite monkeys you would not need infinite time, because when every monkey have typed the length of the complete works of William Shakespeare one will have done it correct.[/quote]
But the monkeys wouldn’t ever finish because there is an infinite amount of moneys, a never ending supply of typing couldn’t ever end.

Read full topic

item.title: Infinite Monkey Theorem
item.dc:creator: @Evil1 Evil_
item.description:
@Evil1 wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:17, topic:347553”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=443931.msg3261311#msg3261311 date=1278525174]

Ohh i was thinking there was an infinite amount of monkeys, not time, because of mopmans example in another topic:

exactly, enough monkeys will win a war through statistics

how can the infinite monkey theorem be simulated =/

Could you prove the theorem with a quantum computer?

I dunno why you’re asking me that lol. My opinion would be no, because you can’t simulate an infinite amount of time, even with a quantum computer. You may be able to simulate an infinite amount of monkeys though…

If you had infinite monkeys you would not need infinite time, because when every monkey have typed the length of the complete works of William Shakespeare one will have done it correct.
[/quote]But the theorem is for an infinite amount of time, not monkeys?[/quote]The theorem handles both, the amount of monkeys and the amount of time; it tends to mention with an infinite amount of monkeys it could possibly be done on the first try.

The same argument shows why at least one of infinitely many monkeys will produce a text as quickly as it would be produced by a perfectly accurate human typist copying it from the original. In this case Xn = (1 − (1/50)6)n where Xn represents the probability that none of the first n monkeys types banana correctly on their first try. When we consider 100 billion monkeys, the probability falls to 0.17%, and as the number of monkeys n increases, the value of Xn – the probability of the monkeys failing to reproduce the given text – approaches zero arbitrarily closely. The limit, for n going to infinity, is zero.

Read full topic

item.title: Infinite Monkey Theorem
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

xx matty xx:

how can the infinite monkey theorem be simulated =/

[quote=“wikipedia”]The infinite monkey theorem states that a monkey hitting keys at random on a typewriter keyboard for an infinite amount of time will almost surely type a given text, such as the complete works of William Shakespeare.
In this context, “almost surely” is a mathematical term with a precise meaning, and the “monkey” is not an actual monkey, but a metaphor for an abstract device that produces a random sequence of letters ad infinitum.[/quote]

Read full topic
